natural problem:
The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$
natural solution: Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. (q o p o r) x = x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (r^-1 o p^-1 o q^-1) x = x"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. (q o p o r) x = x"
shows  "\<forall> x. (r^-1 o p^-1 o q^-1) x = x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If $p$, $q$, and $r$ are bijective functions, and for all $x$, the composition of $q$, $p$, and $r$ applied to $x$ equals $x$ (i.e., $(q \circ p \circ r)(x) = x$), then prove that for all $x$, the composition of the inverses of $r$, $p$, and $q$ applied to $x$ equals $x$ (i.e., $(r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1})(x) = x$).

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "inv f = (\<lambda> x. r (p (q x)))"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "inv f = (\<lambda> x. r (p (q x)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume that $p$, $q$, and $r$ are bijective functions, and $f(x) = q(p(r(x)))$. What is the inverse of $f$? The final answer is $r(p(q(x)))$.

a_2.formal problem:
datatype Function = p | q | r

definition f :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"f = (\<lambda> p q r. q o p o r)"

definition A :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"A = (\<lambda> r q p. inv r o inv q o inv p)"

definition B :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"B = (\<lambda> p q r. inv p o inv q o inv r)"

definition C :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"C = (\<lambda> r p q. inv r o inv p o inv q)"

definition D :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"D = (\<lambda> q p r. inv q o inv p o inv r)"

definition E :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"E = (\<lambda> q r p. inv q o inv r o inv p)"

definition F :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"F = (\<lambda> p r q. inv p o inv r o inv q)"

theorem
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
shows  "f p q r = C r p q"

end
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)



datatype Function = p | q | r

definition f :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"f = (\<lambda> p q r. q o p o r)"

definition A :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"A = (\<lambda> r q p. inv r o inv q o inv p)"

definition B :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"B = (\<lambda> p q r. inv p o inv q o inv r)"

definition C :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"C = (\<lambda> r p q. inv r o inv p o inv q)"

definition D :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"D = (\<lambda> q p r. inv q o inv p o inv r)"

definition E :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"E = (\<lambda> q r p. inv q o inv r o inv p)"

definition F :: "Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function \<Rightarrow> Function" where
"F = (\<lambda> p r q. inv p o inv r o inv q)"

theorem
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
shows  "f p q r = C r p q"

end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Suppose we have three functions, p, q, and r, which are all bijective. We define a new function f composed of these functions as f(p, q, r) = q o p o r. 

We also define six other functions:

- Function A is defined as A(r, q, p) = inv r o inv q o inv p.
- Function B is defined as B(p, q, r) = inv p o inv q o inv r.
- Function C is defined as C(r, p, q) = inv r o inv p o inv q.
- Function D is defined as D(q, p, r) = inv q o inv p o inv r.
- Function E is defined as E(q, r, p) = inv q o inv r o inv p.
- Function F is defined as F(p, r, q) = inv p o inv r o inv q.

Prove that the function f is equal to the function C, i.e., f(p, q, r) = C(r, p, q).

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "(inv f) x = (inv r) ((inv p) ((inv q) x))"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "(inv f) x = (inv r) ((inv p) ((inv q) x))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given three bijective functions $p$, $q$, and $r$, and a function $f$ such that for all $x$, $f(x) = q(p(r(x)))$, find the inverse function of $f$. The final answer is $(r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1})(x)$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r :: "('a \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "f = q o p o r"
shows  "(inv f) = (inv r) o (inv p) o (inv q)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r :: "('a \<Rightarrow> 'a) \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "f = q o p o r"
shows  "(inv f) = (inv r) o (inv p) o (inv q)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If $p$, $q$, and $r$ are bijective functions and $f$ is the composite function $q \circ p \circ r$, find the inverse of $f$. The final answer is $(r^{-1}) \circ (p^{-1}) \circ (q^{-1})$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. inv_f x = r⁻¹ (p⁻¹ (q⁻¹ x))"
shows  "inv_f = f⁻¹"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. inv_f x = r⁻¹ (p⁻¹ (q⁻¹ x))"
shows  "inv_f = f⁻¹"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Assume that $p$, $q$, and $r$ are all bijective functions. Furthermore, assume that for all $x$, $f(x)$ equals the composition of $q$, $p$, and $r$ applied to $x$ (in that order). Also assume that for all $x$, the inverse of $f$ applied to $x$ equals the composition of the inverses of $r$, $p$, and $q$ applied to $x$ (in that order). Prove that the inverse of $f$ is equal to $f$ inverted.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real => real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "inv f = inv r o inv p o inv q"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r f :: "real => real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
shows  "inv f = inv r o inv p o inv q"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If $f(x) = q(p(r(x)))$ where $p$, $q$, and $r$ are all bijections, find the inverse function of $f$. The inverse function of $f$ is $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'b"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "f = q o (p o r)"
shows  "inv f = inv r o (inv p o inv q)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'b"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "f = q o (p o r)"
shows  "inv f = inv r o (inv p o inv q)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assuming that $p$, $q$, and $r$ are bijective functions, and given that function $f$ is the composition of functions $q$ and $p$ after $r$, i.e., $f=q \circ (p \circ r)$, find the inverse function of $f$. The final answer is the composition of the inverse of $r$, $p$, and $q$ in order, i.e., $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ (p^{-1} \circ q^{-1})$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f p q r :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and p_inv q_inv r_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. p (p_inv x) = x \<and> p_inv (p x) = x"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. q (q_inv x) = x \<and> q_inv (q x) = x"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. r (r_inv x) = x \<and> r_inv (r x) = x"
shows  "\<forall> x. f_inv x = r_inv (p_inv (q_inv x))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The functions $p(x),$ $q(x),$ and $r(x)$ are all invertible.  We set
\[f = q \circ p \circ r.\]Which is the correct expression for $f^{-1}$?

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

B. $p^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f p q r :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and p_inv q_inv r_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. f x = q (p (r x))"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. p (p_inv x) = x \<and> p_inv (p x) = x"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. q (q_inv x) = x \<and> q_inv (q x) = x"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. r (r_inv x) = x \<and> r_inv (r x) = x"
shows  "\<forall> x. f_inv x = r_inv (p_inv (q_inv x))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given three bijective (one-to-one and onto) functions p, q, and r, and another function f defined as the composition of q, p, and r (in that order), i.e., f(x) = q(p(r(x))). Also given are the inverses of p, q, and r such that for all x, p(p_inv(x)) = x, q(q_inv(x)) = x, and r(r_inv(x)) = x. What would the inverse of f be in terms of the inverses of p, q, and r? The final answer is that for all x, the inverse of f is the composition of the inverses of r, p, and q (in that order), i.e., f_inv(x) = r_inv(p_inv(q_inv(x))).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"

A. $r^{-1} \circ q^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

C. $r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

D. $q^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ r^{-1}$

E. $q^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ p^{-1}$

F. $p^{-1} \circ r^{-1} \circ q^{-1}$

Enter the letter of the correct expression for $f^{-1}.$ The final Answer is \text{C}
 ### Proof
 Let $y = f(x) = q(p(r(x))).$  Applying $q^{-1},$ we get \[q^{-1}(y) = p(r(x)).\]Applying $p^{-1},$ we get \[p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y)) = r(x).\]Finally, applying $r^{-1}(x),$ we get \[r^{-1}(p^{-1}(q^{-1}(y))) = x.\]Hence, $f^{-1} = r^{-1} \circ p^{-1} \circ q^{-1}.$  The correct answer is $\boxed{\text{C}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes p q r :: "'a \<Rightarrow> 'a"
assumes h0 : "bij p"
and h1 : "bij q"
and h2 : "bij r"
and h3 : "f = q o p o r"
shows  "(inv f) = r^-1 o p^-1 o q^-1"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that functions $p$, $q$, and $r$ are bijections, and $f$ is defined as the composition of $q$, $p$, and $r$ (i.e., $f = q \circ p \circ r$), find the inverse of $f$. The final answer is the composition of the inverses of $r$, $p$, and $q$ in reverse order (i.e., $(f^{-1}) = (r^{-1}) \circ (p^{-1}) \circ (q^{-1})$).
